sources: Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW)
Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife (ODFW)
California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW)
Alaska Department of Fish and Game (ADFG)
notes: Regulations are subject to change. Always verify with official state agencies before fishing.
Federal waters regulations may differ from state waters.
Emergency orders and proclamations may supersede published regulations.
Salmon seasons are typically announced annually in April after population assessments.
Some regulations vary by geographic sub-regions and marine management areas within states.
Pacific states have complex marine area designations - consult local regulations for specific areas.

license_requirements.freshwater: Freshwater fishing license required for age 15+
license_requirements.saltwater: Saltwater fishing license required for age 15+
license_requirements.notes: Regulations valid July 1, 2025 through June 30, 2026. Two-pole endorsement available. Steelhead Card required for steelhead fishing. Separate licenses for freshwater and saltwater.

species.minimum_size_notes: Size varies by marine area: 20-24 inches. 22 inches common in many Puget Sound areas.
species.bag_limit_notes: Daily limit is 2 salmon total; up to 1 may be a Chinook. In some areas, 2 additional pink salmon may be retained.
species.special_regulations: Release wild Chinook in many areas. 2026 is an odd-year cycle with limited pink salmon. Mark-selective fisheries may apply.
species.geographic_restrictions: Complex regulations vary by marine area (1-13). Different rules for Puget Sound vs coastal waters.

species.minimum_size_notes: No minimum size in most areas
species.bag_limit_notes: Included in 2 salmon daily limit. Release wild coho in many areas - only hatchery-marked fish (adipose fin clipped) may be retained in mark-selective fisheries.
species.special_regulations: Mark-selective coho fisheries common. Release wild coho in many Puget Sound areas.

species.bag_limit_notes: 2 additional pink salmon may be retained beyond the 2 salmon daily limit in some areas
species.special_regulations: 2026 is an odd-year cycle - limited pink salmon expected. Pink salmon primarily return in odd years to Puget Sound.

species.bag_limit_notes: Release sockeye in many Puget Sound marine areas. Check specific area regulations.
species.special_regulations: Must be released in many areas. Limited harvest opportunities.
species.geographic_restrictions: Highly restricted in most marine areas

species.bag_limit_notes: Release chum in many Puget Sound marine areas. Check specific area regulations.
species.special_regulations: Must be released in many marine areas

species.minimum_size_notes: No minimum size restriction
species.bag_limit_notes: 1 fish daily catch limit. 6 fish annual bag limit.
species.season_closed: May 24 (specific dates: April 30-May 16 Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays; May 22-24 for Memorial Day weekend)
species.special_regulations: Very limited season. Pending issuance of regulations by National Marine Fisheries Service. Check for updates.
species.geographic_restrictions: All marine areas open to halibut fishing

species.minimum_size_notes: Size limits may vary by area
species.bag_limit_notes: 2 lingcod per day
species.special_regulations: Seasonal closure. Check marine area specific regulations.

species.bag_limit_notes: 7 rockfish in Marine Areas 1-3 and Marine Area 4 west of Bonilla-Tatoosh Line. Sub-limit of 5 canary rockfish. 0 possession limit for copper, quillback, and vermilion rockfish in May, June, July.
species.special_regulations: Some rockfish species have zero possession limits during certain months. Yelloweye rockfish heavily restricted.

species.bag_limit_notes: 2 hatchery steelhead per day. Release all wild steelhead (intact adipose fin).
species.special_regulations: Steelhead Card required. Wild steelhead must be released 100% - only hatchery fish (adipose fin clipped) may be retained. Coastal steelhead regulations set seasonally.
species.geographic_restrictions: Specific regulations for each river system and region

species.common_name: Trout (General - Rainbow, Cutthroat, Brook, Brown, Golden, Tiger)
species.scientific_name: Oncorhynchus spp., Salmo spp., Salvelinus spp.
species.minimum_size_notes: 8 inches minimum in rivers, streams, and beaver ponds; no minimum in lakes, ponds, and reservoirs
species.bag_limit_notes: 2 trout per day in rivers, streams, and beaver ponds; 5 per day in lakes, ponds, and reservoirs
species.special_regulations: Many water bodies have special regulations. Check specific water body rules.

species.minimum_size_notes: Slot limits on some waters
species.bag_limit_notes: 10 bass statewide; only 1 smallmouth over 14 inches may be retained
species.special_regulations: Recent regulation changes increased bag limit. Check specific water body regulations for slot limits.
species.geographic_restrictions: Statewide with some water body exceptions

species.minimum_size_notes: 14 inch protection for larger fish
species.bag_limit_notes: 10 bass total; only 1 smallmouth over 14 inches may be retained
species.special_regulations: Protection for larger spawning fish - only 1 over 14 inches

species.bag_limit_notes: 8 walleye per day with minimum 12 inch size
species.special_regulations: Specific regulations for retaining larger walleye in some waters

species.bag_limit_notes: No daily limit or possession limit
species.season_open: Summer and early fall (August-September most popular)
species.special_regulations: Typically caught 40-100 miles offshore

species.minimum_size_notes: 6.25 inch carapace width in Puget Sound; 6 inches on coast; 5.75 inches in Columbia River
species.bag_limit_notes: 5 Dungeness crab in Puget Sound; 6 on coast; 12 in Columbia River. Males only, hard-shell condition.
species.special_regulations: Males only. Hard-shell condition required. Size and bag limits vary by region.
species.geographic_restrictions: Different regulations for Puget Sound, coastal waters, and Columbia River

species.minimum_size_notes: No minimum carapace size
species.bag_limit_notes: 25 pounds heads and tails of all shrimp species combined. Maximum 200 spot shrimp.
species.special_regulations: Daylight hours only. Seasons vary by marine area and may close when quotas are reached.

license_requirements.saltwater: Angling license required for age 12+. Ocean Endorsement required starting January 1, 2026 for most ocean anglers.
license_requirements.notes: Combined Sport Fishing License (CSFL) valid for all state waters. Ocean Endorsement ($15) required for ocean fishing starting January 1, 2026. Separate salmon and steelhead tags may be required.

species.minimum_size_notes: 22 inches north of Cape Falcon; 24 inches south of Cape Falcon
species.bag_limit_notes: 2 salmon per day, but no more than 1 may be Chinook
species.season_closed: Variable - Chinook retention allowed through mid-July and during September-October
species.special_regulations: When Chinook retention is allowed (June 7 onward), only 1 Chinook as part of 2 salmon daily limit. Seasons announced annually in April.
species.geographic_restrictions: Different size limits north and south of Cape Falcon. Regional variations.

species.bag_limit_notes: 2 salmon daily; all coho must have healed adipose fin clip (mark-selective)
species.season_closed: Late August or until marked coho quota reached (44,000 fish quota Cape Falcon to OR/CA border)
species.special_regulations: Mark-selective coho retention - all coho must be hatchery-marked (adipose fin clipped). Closes when quota reached.

species.bag_limit_notes: 2 hatchery steelhead per day in most areas. In Rogue-South Coast: 1 wild steelhead per day, 3 per season (Dec 1 - Apr 30).
species.special_regulations: Hatchery steelhead marked with clipped adipose fin. Wild steelhead (intact adipose fin) must be released in most areas. Some zones allow wild steelhead over 24 inches. Rogue-South Coast has wild steelhead harvest option.
species.geographic_restrictions: Regulations vary significantly by fishing zone

species.bag_limit_notes: 3 fish daily bag limit per angler beginning January 1, 2026
species.special_regulations: Bag limit increased from 2 to 3 fish starting January 1, 2026. Ocean Endorsement required.

species.bag_limit_notes: 4 fish daily bag limit for general marine species (rockfish, cabezon, greenling, skates, etc.) beginning January 1, 2026. Canary rockfish sub-limit of 2 fish.
species.special_regulations: Yelloweye and quillback rockfish prohibited at all times in all waters. Canary rockfish 2-fish sub-limit. Ocean Endorsement required.

species.bag_limit_notes: 1 fish daily sub-bag limit as part of general marine bag limit beginning July 1, 2026
species.special_regulations: Seasonal closure January 1 - June 30. Part of 4-fish general marine species aggregate. Ocean Endorsement required.

species.bag_limit_notes: Bag limit announced in April. Quota-based fishery.
species.season_closed: August-October (generally occurs May through August, can last into October)
species.special_regulations: Season and bag limits announced annually in April. Quota-based fishery that may close early when quota reached.

species.bag_limit_notes: 15 fish aggregate limit across all surfperch species per day
species.special_regulations: Aggregate limit for all surfperch species combined

species.bag_limit_notes: 25 fish aggregate across all flatfish species
species.special_regulations: Aggregate limit for all flatfish species

species.bag_limit_notes: 25 fish per day
species.special_regulations: Ocean Endorsement required

license_requirements.freshwater: Sport fishing license required for age 16+
license_requirements.saltwater: Sport fishing license required for age 16+ for ocean fishing. Sport Ocean Enhancement Validation ($7.30) required for fishing south of Point Arguello.
license_requirements.notes: Steelhead Report Card ($10.29) required for steelhead in anadromous waters. North Coast Salmon Report Card ($9.21) required for salmon in Klamath, Trinity, and Smith rivers. Ocean salmon seasons announced annually in April.

species.bag_limit_notes: 2 Chinook salmon statewide daily bag limit. Once ashore, no more than 2 bag limits (4 fish) may be possessed.
species.special_regulations: Ocean salmon seasons announced annually in April after population assessments. On vessel, no person may possess more than 1 daily bag limit. Check NMFS ocean salmon hotline (800) 662-9825 for in-season changes.
species.geographic_restrictions: Season dates vary by management area

species.bag_limit_notes: No coho salmon may be retained in ocean fisheries off California
species.special_regulations: Retention of coho salmon prohibited statewide in all ocean fisheries

species.bag_limit_notes: 10 total Rockfish, Cabezon, and Greenling in aggregate. 2-fish sub-bag limit for Canary Rockfish.
species.special_regulations: Bronzespotted, Cowcod, Quillback, and Yelloweye Rockfish may not be taken or possessed at any time. Always check for in-season changes. Minimum size limits for most rockfish species eliminated as of 2025.
species.geographic_restrictions: Varies by management area. Boat-based closure Jan 1 - Mar 31.

species.minimum_size_notes: 22 inches whole fish; fillets must be at least 14 inches when filleted at sea
species.bag_limit_notes: Check current regulations for daily bag limit
species.special_regulations: Part of 10-fish rockfish/cabezon/greenling aggregate in some areas. May be filleted at sea.

species.minimum_size_notes: Minimum size limit eliminated as of 2025
species.bag_limit_notes: Within 10-fish rockfish/cabezon/greenling aggregate
species.special_regulations: May be filleted at sea. When possessed onboard or brought ashore, fillets must have entire skin attached.

species.bag_limit_notes: Check regional bag limits
species.special_regulations: 22 inch total length minimum

species.bag_limit_notes: Check current regulations
species.season_closed: March 15 - June 15 south of Point Conception
species.special_regulations: Seasonal closure south of Point Conception March 15 - June 15. Active biting offshore in San Diego and Dana Point in summer.
species.geographic_restrictions: Closure south of Point Conception during spawning season

species.bag_limit_notes: Check current regulations
species.special_regulations: Appears near Catalina Island starting in April

species.bag_limit_notes: Check current regulations for specific bag limits
species.special_regulations: Starts to appear near Catalina Island in April

species.bag_limit_notes: 5 per day combined with calico bass
species.special_regulations: Combined 5-fish limit with calico bass

species.minimum_size_notes: Varies by water body; 12 inches for most lakes and Delta
species.bag_limit_notes: Possession limit of 10
species.season_open: Year-round for lakes and reservoirs; April 25 for streams/rivers
species.special_regulations: Specific regulations vary by water body. Check special regulations for location.
species.geographic_restrictions: Different seasons for lakes/reservoirs vs streams/rivers

species.bag_limit_notes: Steelhead Report Card required. Only hatchery steelhead (adipose fin clipped) may be retained in many waters; wild steelhead must be released.
species.special_regulations: Steelhead defined as rainbow trout >16 inches in anadromous waters. Wild fish (intact adipose fin) must be released in many areas.
species.geographic_restrictions: Specific regulations for each anadromous water system

species.minimum_size_notes: Varies by water body
species.bag_limit_notes: Statewide daily bag limit; check for specific water body exceptions
species.special_regulations: Check specific regulations for each water body

license_requirements.freshwater: Sport fishing license required for age 16+
license_requirements.saltwater: Sport fishing license required for age 16+
license_requirements.notes: Regulations vary significantly by drainage and management area. Emergency Orders (EOs) supersede published regulations - check before fishing. Alaska fishing license valid for both fresh and saltwater.

species.minimum_size_notes: Southeast Alaska and Yakutat region
species.bag_limit_notes: 1 per day for residents (Southeast/Yakutat). Limits vary by region and residency.
species.special_regulations: Specific to Southeast Alaska and Yakutat. Check area-specific regulations. King Salmon stamp may be required.
species.geographic_restrictions: Regulations vary significantly by region and drainage

species.minimum_size_notes: 16 inches or longer in saltwater (Southeast Alaska)
species.bag_limit_notes: 6 per day in Southeast Alaska saltwater (16+ inches); 12 in possession. Some areas like Sitka: 6 per day, no annual limit.
species.special_regulations: Separate limits for fish under 16 inches (10 per day). Emergency Orders frequently issued.
species.geographic_restrictions: Highly variable by region and drainage

species.minimum_size_notes: 16 inches or longer in saltwater (Southeast Alaska)
species.bag_limit_notes: 6 per day (16+ inches) in Southeast Alaska saltwater; 12 in possession
species.special_regulations: Separate limits for fish under 16 inches (10 per day). Each drainage has specific regulations.

species.minimum_size_notes: 16 inches or longer in saltwater (Southeast Alaska)
species.bag_limit_notes: 6 per day (16+ inches) in Southeast Alaska saltwater; 12 in possession
species.special_regulations: Separate limits for fish under 16 inches (10 per day). Pink salmon return in large numbers in odd years.

species.minimum_size_notes: 16 inches or longer in saltwater (Southeast Alaska)
species.bag_limit_notes: 6 per day (16+ inches) in Southeast Alaska saltwater; 12 in possession. Some areas like Sitka: 6 per day, no annual limit.
species.special_regulations: Separate limits for fish under 16 inches (10 per day). Emergency Orders frequently issued.

species.bag_limit_notes: Nonresidents: 1 daily for unguided. Charter vessels in Homer: 2 daily (1 any size, 1 under 27 inches). Daily limits remained same for 2026 unguided sectors.
species.special_regulations: International Pacific Halibut Commission (IPHC) regulations. Limits vary by charter vs unguided and by management area.
species.geographic_restrictions: Limits vary by management unit (e.g., Homer has different charter limits)

species.bag_limit_notes: Nonresidents: 6 per day for non-pelagic rockfish. Pelagic rockfish in Southeast: 5 daily, 10 possession in some areas.
species.special_regulations: Pelagic rockfish (dusky, dark, widow, blue, yellowtail, black) have different limits than other rockfish. Petersburg, Wrangell, Kake areas have specific pelagic rockfish regulations.
species.geographic_restrictions: Regional variations between pelagic and non-pelagic species

species.bag_limit_notes: Nonresidents: 1 fish daily with annual limit of 1 fish, July 1 through August 25
species.special_regulations: Highly restricted. Annual limit of 1 fish for nonresidents. Limited season.

species.common_name: Pelagic Rockfish (Dusky, Dark, Widow, Blue, Yellowtail, Black)
species.bag_limit_notes: Nonresidents: 3 fish per day, no annual limit. Some Southeast areas: 5 daily, 10 possession.
species.special_regulations: Pelagic species have more liberal limits than other rockfish. Petersburg, Wrangell, Kake areas may have 5 daily/10 possession limits.

species.minimum_size_notes: 30-35 inches OR 55+ inches; Central Gulf: 35 inches minimum
species.bag_limit_notes: 1 per day, 1 in possession. Annual limit: 2 fish (1 at 30-35 inches, 1 at 55+ inches).
species.special_regulations: Slot limit with option for one trophy fish. Annual limit of 2 fish with size requirements. Size limits vary by region.
species.geographic_restrictions: Size limits differ by region (Southeast vs Central Gulf)

species.bag_limit_notes: Sport fishing bag limits vary by area - check specific regulations
species.special_regulations: 2026 commercial guideline harvest range: 750,000-1,250,000 pounds for NSEI and SSEI combined. Sport fishing regulations separate.
species.geographic_restrictions: Commercial regulations for Northern and Southern Southeast Inside subdistricts

license_requirements.freshwater: No license required for recreational fishing
license_requirements.saltwater: No license required for recreational saltwater fishing
license_requirements.notes: Commercial marine license required to sell catch. HMS (Highly Migratory Species) permit required for tunas and billfish - either HMS Angling permit or HMS Charter/Headboat permit. Recreational anglers cannot sell their catch.

species.minimum_size_notes: 27 inches curved fork length (federal Atlantic regulation; verify Hawaii-specific rules). 3 pounds minimum for sale.
species.bag_limit_notes: 3 fish per angler per day or trip (federal regulation)
species.special_regulations: HMS permit required. Federal regulations apply - verify Hawaii state regulations may differ.

species.minimum_size_notes: 27 inches curved fork length (federal regulation)
species.bag_limit_notes: No bag limit specified in federal regulations
species.special_regulations: HMS permit required

species.bag_limit_notes: No specific bag limit noted
species.special_regulations: Important commercial and recreational species. No license required for recreational fishing.

species.bag_limit_notes: No specific bag limit noted
species.special_regulations: Small to medium-sized tuna. Important in commercial and recreational fisheries.

species.bag_limit_notes: No specific bag limit for recreational fishing
species.special_regulations: Can be taken by hook-and-line seaward of 20-fathom depth contour. No license required for recreational fishing.

species.bag_limit_notes: No specific bag limit noted
species.special_regulations: Important troll fishery target. No license required for recreational fishing.

species.minimum_size_notes: 99 inches lower jaw fork length (federal regulation)
species.bag_limit_notes: No daily limit but 250 fish per vessel per year combined for blue marlin, white marlin, and roundscale spearfish (federal)
species.special_regulations: HMS permit required. Important troll fishery target.

species.bag_limit_notes: No specific bag limit noted
species.special_regulations: Important troll fishery target. HMS regulations may apply.

species.minimum_size_notes: 10 inches minimum; 16 inches for sale
species.bag_limit_notes: 20 fish bag limit (non-commercial only)
species.special_regulations: Papio refers to juveniles, ulua to adults. Size for sale is 16 inches. L50 (length at 50% maturity) is 14.7-24 inches.

species.bag_limit_notes: 4 fish bag limit (commercial permits allow higher amounts)
species.special_regulations: Reef fish with specific size and bag limits

species.minimum_size_notes: 10 inches generally; 14 inches for regulated large species
species.bag_limit_notes: 2 total across all parrotfish species
species.special_regulations: No take on Maui for uhu 'ele'ele and uhu uliuli. Strict aggregate bag limit across all species.

species.common_name: Deep 7 Bottomfish (Onaga, Opakapaka, Ehu, Kalekale, Lehi, Ukikiki, Hapu'u)
species.bag_limit_notes: 5 total combined across all Deep 7 species (non-commercial only)
species.special_regulations: Aggregate bag limit for these seven deep-water bottomfish species combined

species.bag_limit_notes: Completely protected - no harvest allowed
species.special_regulations: Unlawful to intentionally or knowingly capture or entangle any shark. Complete protection.

species.bag_limit_notes: Completely protected - no harvest allowed
species.special_regulations: Unlawful to intentionally or knowingly capture or entangle any ray. Complete protection.

pacific_region_notes: Pacific states have complex marine area designations - always consult local area-specific regulations
Salmon regulations are announced annually in April after population assessments
Emergency orders are common, especially in Alaska - check before every fishing trip
Many Pacific salmon and steelhead fisheries are mark-selective (hatchery vs wild)
Federal HMS permit required for highly migratory species (tunas, marlins, swordfish)
International Pacific Halibut Commission (IPHC) manages halibut across Pacific states
Ocean Endorsements becoming more common (Oregon 2026, California in some areas)
Rockfish species have complex regulations - some species completely protected
Hawaii has no recreational fishing license but commercial sales require permits
Alaska regulations vary dramatically by drainage, region, and residency status
data_gaps: Some specific bag limits not available in search results
Detailed freshwater species coverage could be expanded
Shellfish regulations (clams, oysters, mussels, sea urchins) not included
Tribal fishing regulations and reserved rights not covered
Spearfishing and free diving regulations not detailed
Specific marine protected areas and no-take zones not mapped
Charter/for-hire vessel regulations may differ from private recreational
Some Hawaii species need verification of state vs federal regulations
recommendations: Always verify current regulations before fishing - these change frequently
Check for emergency orders, especially in Alaska and for salmon seasons
Download state-specific fishing apps (Fish Rules, WDFW Fish Washington, etc.)
Carry printed regulations pamphlet while fishing
Learn to identify hatchery vs wild fish (adipose fin clips)
Understand proper measurement techniques (total length vs fork length vs curved fork length)
Be aware of marine area boundaries - GPS recommended
Know the difference between bag limits, possession limits, vessel limits, and annual limits
Respect protected species - yelloweye rockfish, cowcod, some parrotfish, all sharks/rays in Hawaii
Consider hiring guides for first-time fishing in complex regulatory areas
future_expansions: Add shellfish and invertebrate regulations (crab, shrimp, clams, urchins, etc.)
Include detailed freshwater species for all Pacific states
Add tribal fishing regulations and co-management areas
Include marine protected areas and no-take zones
Add spearfishing and free diving specific regulations
Add information about fishing methods restrictions (gear types, bait restrictions)
Add contact information for each state agency
Include links to official regulation documents and hotlines
Add seasonal migration patterns and peak fishing times
Include invasive species regulations and reporting requirements
